content:
Done, Thanks for the suggestions.

I have added and clarified in several places, plus notations under "Missing Log File"

  • If logging imap, you must use [[MailNews:Logging#Gecko_Logging|Gecko module logging]] using environment variables.
creator: wsmwk

content:
OK. I tried, but I really don't have the patience or the time to register with yet another web site.

Could you do the honors, please? :-)

This is what needs to be changed:

https://wiki.mozilla.org/MailNews:Logging#Linux.2Funix

  • Add quote marks around variables' values.
  • Indicate that the path to the log file must be fully specified (i.e. without shortcuts, such as "~/").

https://wiki.mozilla.org/MailNews:Logging#Gecko_Logging

  • Change the sentence that reads "may be enabled via preferences (not discussed in this document), or command line, which is discussed here." to "is enabled via environment variables, as follows:"

I sent an email to the webmaster of thunderbird-mail.de (the ONLY other place that has this information) with these changes. Hopefully he'll get my message.

Thanks!
creator: blackblue1

content: I can tweak the wiki after you give it a shot.
creator: wsmwk

content:
OK. That was the push I needed to try one more thing and it worked.

The variables' values must be enclosed in quotes (")

AND

The name of the log file and its path must be fully specified (i.e. "~/" doesn't work).

These commands did the trick:

export MOZ_LOG="IMAP:5,timestamp"

export MOZ_LOG_FILE="/home/[username]/logs/imap.log"

/media/data-e/downld/Thunderbird/thunderbird/thunderbird-bin

I'll try to update the wiki. If I can't, hopefully someone else will do it.

Thanks for your help!
creator: blackblue1

content: "Gecko logging may be enabled via preferences" is inaccurate. For imap you must use command line variables with log module names listed in that section.
creator: wsmwk

content:
Hi,

Sorry I wasn't clear. I tried the instructions under Gecko logging as well and no log file is ever created.

The only other source of information I could find has the same instructions as the wiki under Gecko logging (https://www.thunderbird-mail.de/lexicon/entry/215-protokoll-log-datei-der-server-verbindung-mit-imap-pop-und-smtp-erstellen/).

The first paragraph of the gecko section in the wiki - https://wiki.mozilla.org/MailNews:Logging#Gecko_Logging - indicates that "Gecko logging may be enabled via preferences," but I couldn't find any preference that contains the word "gecko."

I wonder what I might be missing here.

Interestingly, I just added quote marks around the environment variables' values and at least got logging output sent to the console (no log files created, though).

Thanks!!!
creator: blackblue1

content:
mailnews.imap.loglevel is the modern style, but this is not yet used in release versions of Thunderbird.

You should be using Gecko logging https://wiki.mozilla.org/MailNews:Logging#Gecko_Logging

creator: BSM1

content:
sfhowes said

BSM1 said

Followed the procedure. TB is exactly the same.

There are a number of pitfalls in applying userChrome: check that the file is a Cascading Style Sheet type, and not plain text.

Indeed. If you are on Windows and it's set to hide file extensions for known file types (the default), you can come a cropper. You may end up with a file that appears to be named `userChrome.css` but is actually named `userChrome.css.txt`. (You should change the Windows setting anyway, otherwise you could inadvertently open malicious email attachments which appear to be named something like `cute-cat-pic.jpeg` but are actually named `cute-cat-pic.jpeg.exe` and if allowed to run will install a virus, worm or trojan. It beggars belief that Microsoft thought it was a good idea to hide file extensions, given that at the time they did this, with the release of Windows XP, their OS was still packed with security vulnerabilities.)

After applying the config file change, you need to restart TB.
creator: jake12

content:
BSM1 said
Followed the procedure. TB is exactly the same.

There are a number of pitfalls in applying userChrome: check that the file is a Cascading Style Sheet type, and not plain text. Using the online generator avoids this error. Check that the chrome folder is a subfolder of the active profile.

content:
At the moment, the Unified Bar is the only place you can pin buttons from the Customize window.

The bar can be hidden, and the Menu Bar moved to the top, with css: 

#toolbar-menubar { order: -1 !important;}  unified-toolbar { display: none !important;}


Help/Troubleshooting Info (TB 115), Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, create a new folder named chrome, create a new document in chrome with a text editor, name it userChrome.css, Save as type: All files *.*, copy in the above code. Double-click toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets to true in Settings/General/Config. editor, restart TB.

Online css generator

content:
Thunderbird has had support for Yahoo's Oauth2 (modern authentication) for some years now. If you use Yahoo's servers to access your Sky mail, then Thunderbird works just fine. When adding the account in Thunderbird, select Configure manually then use the settings given here https://uk.help.yahoo.com/kb/sky/SLN4075.html

Set Authentication method to OAuth2 and you're good to go.

content:
When you ask a question, you are provided with an area to type information which explains more about the problem and offer infor about your OS, version of Thunderbird you are using and your set up. It's useful to state what steps you take and what you expect and what you get.

"Fix it" does not offer anyone any information.

Please provide some info about this situation. What OS are you using ? What version of Thunderbird are you using? Are you talking about an imap or pop mail account?

What do you mean by "does not read my emails"? You read emails not Thunderbird. Do you mean you cannot connect to server to download emails ? If yes, then what error message message are you seeing? Post an image of the error message or state what it says word for word.

Do you mean emails are downloaded but you cannot see them in Message List? Do you mean you can see them in Message List but when you select them no content is shown?

You also say "or mark them as read" - maybe this is the actual problem? So that implies you are downloading emails and are able to read them.

Do you use Message Filters to move new emails to folders? Do you find the 'not mark as read' only effects emails you have filtered to other folders, but those in Inbox are ok. Do you have any Message Filter which sets up a Mark as Read or Unread?

The 'Mark as read' issue: Do you have the following settings ?

  • Settings > General
  • scroll to 'Reading & Display'
  • Select 'Automatically mark messages as read'
  • Select 'Immediately on display'

Do you use an addon extensions ? If yes, then please perform a test

  • Help > Troubleshoot Mode
  • Click on 'REstart' and seelct 'Continue in Troubleshoot Mode'

Use this mode for a while to see if the 'mark as read' works when you open an email. REport on results.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
settings>General scroll down to 'config editor' look for this line: mail.identity.default.suppress_signature_separator; false Double click to toggle 'false' to 'true' or right click on line and select 'Toggle' Close config editor - top right X click on OK to save changes in Options.

That feature is used by many email clients, not just Thunderbird, as the line from which signatures are stripped when replying to message.

content:
There was a recent issue with a different provider (Optimum), where users with non-secure settings were suddenly unable to send or receive. Changing to the recommended secure settings fixed it.

The fact the account is working in webmail is not relevant to its performance in TB, as the two use different systems.

I suggest you contact Westnet to confirm if your non-secure settings are still supported. Also, try running Windows in safe mode to test if Bitdefender is interfering with secure connections. Disabling BD is not sufficient to rule out its effect.
creator: sfhowes

content:
I changed the secure settings using both choices (SSL/TLS and STARTTLS) with no success. I even turned off my Bitdefender firewall while experimenting.

As I mentioned, I have not changed the settings in Thunderbird at all. And what doesn't make sense is the other email address, which is on the same Thunderbird program as the problematic one, is having no issues whatsoever AND the settings are exactly the same. The only difference is the wendyp uses "wn" and not "westnet". The "wn" is because it's an old Westnet email address.

I have been able to get into my webmail on my ISPs website, and send/receive emails on the wendyp email with no issues. Hence the reason it has to be Thunderbird.

I've had these settings on Thunderbird for many years and had my email address for decades. I don't understand what has changed.
creator: isthisurcard3

content:
Your picture shows the settings for the incoming POP server with connection security = none, and I assume it's the same for the outgoing (which is why the error is 'relay denied'). According to their site, you should be using secure settings:

incoming POP server: mail.westnet.com.au port: 995 Connection security: SSL/TLS Authentication: normal password User Name: email address

outgoing SMTP server: mail.westnet.com.au port: 587 Connection security: STARTTLS Authentication: normal password User Name: email address
creator: sfhowes
